results.name: doctr
results.text:
17
was a race up to that time among non-Moslem peoples whieh with sineere and deep feeling
honored the Ottoman fatherland that race was the Armenian. It is the Armenians who
wear most nearly the national dress, who speak and write Turkish best, and recognize the
Ottoman country as their fatherland. Besides this it is the Armenians who
in
eommerce and agriculture, and thus, by demonstrating its fruitfulness, increase the engatec of
the Ottoman Empire. Beeause a few among them justly started an agitation, these our noble
and industrions brethren were being massacred. What a terrible scene! When we
left the school building we saw hundreds of the bodies of our Armenian compatriots being
removed in mamure carts ; legs and arms were hanging down outside. This bloody scene will
ever remain impressed on my mind. X
<6' This shocking crime of Yildiz formed a deep lake of blood, and this lake, during the
whole course of a cursed absolutism,
to the last moment, grew wider. Even during the
past nine months ofthe Constitution, i spite of the brotherly feelings which had been shown,
the awful events in Adana took plaee and the souls ofall true Osmanlis melted into tears.
Up to the present time the deep sorrow cansed by this event has not disappeared, because this
bloody wound in our social body cannot easily be cured. While we fill our stomachs with
choice morsels, while we rest selfishly in our comfortable beds, these fatherless and brotherless
orphans, widows hungry, naked, and barefoot wander hither and thither, and thousands of
families are fleeing from the fatherland. Weare convinced that the government is doing its
work, but what has happened is sO great a calamity that it can keep a government husy for
years. However much sacrifice we may make, still it will be inadequate, because the
happiness of the fatherland depends on healing such blood wounds as these as soon as possible.
Weare convineed that the government-andalt: connected with itare persuaded ofthis as well as
ourselves. We must now wipe out the traces ofthe misfortune brought by a eursed period.
We must now comfort weeping hearts. We must understand and teach those who do not
understand that patriotism and brotherhood do not differ from each other. The responsibility
oft the government for the Armenians is very great and very weighty. The whole Ottoman
nation is under obligations to proteet this suffering race, because the liberty we enjoy to-day
is in large part due to the blood shed by the Armenians. We thought that these trutlis
were SO obvious that we preferred to keep silence, whereas to-day we understand that itis
neeessary from time to time to recall the greatness of our obligation. We must not forget
that this unhappy people up to yesterday has endured only barbarism, and for twelve years
has been constantly oppressed and ground to the earth, and has given thousands of victims.
Hereafter we must work to assure them that the era of massaeres has passed, and with all our
strength of mind and soul we must quiet them. The obligation of the government to protect
them is also veryl heavy, hecause our Armenian countrymen live among wandering tribes.
We must all assist the government and point out its obligation. It must be declared in
public and periodically that the one of the most important duties of the Ottoman nation is to
protect, together with those of other races, the interests, the life, and property of the
Armenians as well, since these are their saered rights. Let investigations be made and let
whatever is necessary be done in order to reach this aim."
This article of the Turkish officer, who however does not dare disclose
his identity , and the account given by an authority like Mr. James Bryce
surely refute the facile explanation of Ahmed Riza Bey in alluding to the
Massacres as s les Massacres occasionnès par les aventuriers Arméniens."
Indeed it holds out poor hope for the furtherance of liberty and justice in
Turkey when the man who is the President of the Chamberofl Deputies only

results.text:
17
was a race up to that time among non-Moslem peoples whieh with sineere and deep feeling
honored the Ottoman fatherland that race was the Armenian. It is the Armenians who
wear most nearly the national dress, who speak and write Turkish best, and recognize the
Ottoman eonntry as their fatherland. DBesides this it is the Armenians who engage in
eomnerce and agriculture, and thus, by demonstrating its fruitfulness, inerease the value of
the Ottoman ILmpire.  Beeause a few among them justly started an agitation, these our noble
and industrious brethren were being massaeredl. What a terrible scene! When we
left the school building we saw hundreds of the bodies of our Armenian compatriots being
removed in manure carts ; legs and arms were hanging down outside. "This bloody seene will
ever remain impressed on my mind. |
«This shocking erime of Yildiz formed a deep lake of blood, and this lake, during the
whole course of a eursed absolutism, up to the last moment, grew wider. MKven during the
past nine months of the Constitution, in spite of the brotherly feelings which had been shown,
the awfuł events in Adana took płaee and the souls of all true Osmanlis melted into tears.
Up to the present time the deep sorrow eansed by this event has not disappeared, because this
błoody wound in our social body eannot easily be cured. While we fill our stomachs with
ehoice morsels, while we rest selishly in our comfortable beds, these fatherless and brotherless
orphans, widows hungry, naked, and barefoot wander hither and thither, and thousands of
families are fleeing from the fatherland. We are convinced that the government is doing its
work, but what has happened is so great a ealamity that it can keep a government busy for
years. Tlowever much sacrifice we may make, still it will be inadequate, because the
happiness of the fatherland depends on healing such blood wounds as these as soon us possible.
We are convineed that the government and all connected with it are persuaded of this as well as
oursełyes. We must now wipe out the traces of the misfortune brought by a eursed period.
We must now comfort weeping hearts. We must understand and teach those who do not
understand that patriotism and brotherhood d> not differ from each other. "The responsibility
of the government for the Armenians is very great and very weighty. The whołe Ottoman
nation is under obligations to proteet this sufiering race, because the liberty we enjoy to-day
is in large part due to the blood shed by the Armenians. We thought that these truths
were so obvious that we preferred to keep silence, whereas to-day we understand that it is
necessary from time to time to recall the greatness of owr obligation. We must not forget
that this unhappy people up to yesterday has endured only barbarism, and for twelve years
has been constantly oppressed and ground to the earth, and has given thousands of victims.
Hereafter we must work to assure them that the era of massaeres has passed, and with all our
strength of mind and soul we must quiet them. The obligation of the government to protect
them is also very heavy, because our Armenian conntrymen live among wandering tribes.
We must all assist the government and point out its obligation. It must be declared in
public and periodically that the one of the most important duties of the Ottoman nation is to
protect, together with those of other races, the interests, the life, and property of the
AArmenians as well, since these are their saered rights. Let investigations be made and let
whatever is necessary be done in order to reach this aim.
This article of the Turkish officer, who however does not dare disclose
